com.appreflector.common

Class FXWebApp

  • java.lang.Object
    • javafx.application.Application
      • com.appreflector.common.FXWebApp
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    FXWebApp.FXWebWindow

    public class FXWebApp
extends javafx.application.Application
    FXWebApp is used to embed a JavaFX scene into a browser and support user interaction via JavaScript callbacks in the host environment.

    FXWebApp is likely to be especially useful to web developers who want to use JavaFX in their web pages, but avoid writing/compiling their own Java code.

    An FXWebApp application is embedded in a web page using JavaScript.

    FXWebApp supplements the code in the standard Java Web Deployment Toolkit as follows:

    • Arbitrary JavaFX scenes can be embedded in a web page by loading a user-designed GUI specified in FXML - the Oracle defined markup language for JavaFX.
      Accompanying JavaScript code allows the FXML to be supplied as a file, or in-lined within the hosting HTML document (see below)
    • Web developers can create controllers for their GUIs by coding in JavaScript - there is no need to do further coding in Java. This is achieved by attaching the supplied default controller (FXWebAppController: written in Java). Listeners within this controller automatically forward events to user-written JavaScript callbacks within the host context.
    • Convenience methods are provided to allow users to run JavaScript code from the JavaFX Platform thread - these methods ensure thread-safety.

    FXML
    An extremely polished and versatile IDE for designing JavaFX-based GUIs that creates FXML files as output is freely available from http://gluonhq.com/open-source/scene-builder/. As FXML can be deployed to desktop, web and mobile devices, its use here has the advantage that the same GUI-code can target each environment. Java programmers intending to do that may prefer to add code to the FXWebAppController listeners (or replace it with a custom controller) instead of writing JavaScript callbacks to make porting the code easier.

    USE
    FXWebApp is intended to work alongside the dtjava.js code supplied as part of the Java web deployment toolkit.
    A closed source copy is available from Oracle
    and an open-source copy (GNU GPL v2) as part of the OpenJDK project from here. See Note [1] below.

    Direct use of dtjava.js
    If the dtjava.js embed method is called directly, the following parameters can be supplied and will be forwarded to the FXWebApp start method:
    dtjava.embed( {
    id: appName,
    url: jnlp,
    placeholder: element,
    width: w,
    height: h,
    params: { fxml: fxmlText,
    data: '',
    callbacks: callbacks}});

    Details are as follows:

    • id: appName - the id to be assigned to the embedded application
    • url: jnlp - the fully qualified path and file name to this project's JNLP file
    • placeholder: element - reference to the host element in the HTML file where graphics will be embedded
    • width: w - width of the element
    • height: h - height of the element

    The params field provides data for use in the FXWebApp start methods. These are:
    • fxml - the FXML to parse as a string
    • data - a string containing data (typically as Json) that will be passed to the callbacks. Once the application is embedded, this string can be changed by calling the setData method on the application.
    • callbacks - the name of the JavaScript object in the host context containing the callbacks (if any).

    Use with the accompanying JavaScript code

    An accompanying JavaScript file, fxdeploy-common.js, provides code for specifying use of an FXWebApp from HTML with minimal JavaScript coding.
    To use fxdeploy-common.js, add the following to your HTML header element
    <head>
    ...
    <script src="http://java.com/js/dtjava.js"></script>
    <script src="fxdeploy-common.js"></script>**
    ...
    </head>
    ** this declaration here should include the full path information to the JavaScript file.

    Once loaded, fxdeploy-common.js will create a variable, fxdeploy$common that defines a set of functions. Only one of these is usually of interest:
    fxdeploy$common.init()
    should be called once your HTML document loads. E.g. add the following in your HTML file:
    <body onload="fxdeploy$common.init()">
    This function scans the HTML document for an element marked up as described below and automatically loads the FXML content into it.

    • Creating HTML document for fxdeploy-common.js

      The JavaScript code recognises HTML elements marked up with the following classnames:

      • fxml-placeholder - an element that will be filled with JavaFX contents described in an FXML document (file).
      • fxml-content - an element containing in-line FXML. This will be read and parsed. The JavaFX contents will be generated and replace the in-line FXML.
      • fxml-status - an element that will be updated, if present, with progress information as the FXML loads and is processed by the code.

      Note that only one fxml-placeholder or fxml-content element is permitted per HTML frame. Also, only one fxml-status element is supported per frame.

      • fxml-placeholder

        Placeholders are declared as follows:

        <div class="fxml-placeholder" src='myGUI.fxml' data-appname="myApp" data-callbacks="myCallbacks" data-jnlp="./FXDeploy.jnlp">
        ...
        </div>

        • src - provides the full path and file name of the FXML file
        • data-appname - provides a name for the embedded Java application.
          The application may be accessed, once loaded, by calling to document.getElementById(data-appname);
        • data-callbacks - a string providing the name for the variable containing the JavaScript callbacks for the JavaFX node.
          If data-callbacks is not defined, a default value will be assigned. Either:
          1. fxml$callbacks OR
          2. reflector$callbacks
          if one of these variables is defined in the calling workspace.
          The Java listeners will automatically invoke these callbacks as described below.
        • data-jnlp provides the fully qualified path and file name for the JNLP file containing this Java code.
          Note that fxdeploy-common.js defines a variable close to its start that provides a default value for this. If the data-jnlp is omitted from your HTML, the default value will be used:
          var jnlp_file = '../../../java/FXDeploy/dist/FXDeploy.jnlp';
          This path here needs to be edited to point to a copy of the JNLP file local to your web resource.

      • fxml-content
        To inline the FXML code within an HTML document use
        <div class="fxml-content" data-appname="myApp" data-callbacks="myCallbacks" data-jnlp="./FXDeploy.jnlp">
        <script type="text/plain">
        ...
        </script>
        </div>
        For definitions of the "data-" properties, see the fxml-placeholder entry above.
        The content of the <script> block should be the FXML.
        • Short-form FXML
          If the header information is absent from the FXML, it will be added automatically. Thus you can specify FXML as below:
          <script type="text/plain">
          <Pane prefHeight="400.0" prefWidth="600.0">
          <children>
          <Button fx:id="myButton" layoutX="271.0" layoutY="174.0" text="Hello World!" />
          </children>
          </Pane>
          </script>

          The FXML that is created will be as follows (subject to updates - check the code):

          <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
          <?import java.lang.*?>
          <?import java.util.*?>
          <?import javafx.scene.effect.*?>
          <?import javafx.geometry.Pos.*?>
          <?import javafx.scene.text.*?>
          <?import javafx.scene.*?>
          <?import javafx.scene.control.*?>
          <?import javafx.scene.shape.*?>
          <?import javafx.scene.layout.*?>
          <?import javafx.collections.*?>

          <Pane prefHeight="400.0" prefWidth="600.0" xmlns="http://javafx.com/javafx/8.0.40" xmlns:fx="http://javafx.com/fxml/1">
          <children>
          <Button fx:id="myButton" layoutX="271.0" layoutY="174.0" text="Hello World!" />
          </children>
          </Pane>

        • Fully-formed FXML
          If the inlined <script> starts with "<?xml" it will be used as supplied. Users may therefore customise imports, namespaces etc.
          Note that "xmnls" and "xmlns:fx" may be required and need to be specified by the user in this case.

    CALLBACKS
    The FXWebApp start attaches a controller to the FXWebApp instance. Once initialised, listeners in this controller will forward events to user-supplied JavaScript callbacks.
    Users populate the callbacks with their own JavaScript code. For example:
    fxmlCallbacks: {
    myButton_callback: function(...) {
    ...}}
    In this case, "fxmlCallbacks" would be supplied as the "callbacks" element in the "params" field of the dtjava.embed call or set as the data-callbacks attribute in HTML when using fxdeploy-common.js.

    When not using fxdeploy-common.js, initialisation of the controller that invokes the callbacks needs to be done explicitly from the calling JavaScript once the application is embedded.

    The default FXWebAppController

    The description below is for the default FXWebAppController added in the start method. Java programmers can supply their own controller.

    If the object containing the callbacks was specified as a parameter to the start method simply call initController() e.g.
    document.getElemenyById(appName).initController();
    Otherwise, specify the callback object at initialisation:
    document.getElemenyById(appName).initController(callbackObject);

    FXWebApp maintains a LinkedHashMap<String, Object> that lists the nodes to which listeners/callbacks should be attached. The keys of this HashMap should correspond to the ids (returned by calling getId()) of nodes that descend from the root object defined in the FXML supplied to the start method.
    If this map is left empty, it will be populated automatically during initialisation with the ids of all nodes that have a defined id. In this case, the values corresponding to each key in the LinkedHashMap<String, Object> will be null.
    Alternatively, users can populate the map from javaScript before initialising the controller. In this case, the values in the map can be assigned by the user - and these values will be passed to the JavaScript callbacks (as described below). To populate the map from JavaScript use code such as the following:

    var map = document.getElemenyById(appName).getCallbackObjectMap();
    map.clear();
    map.put('myButton', 'user data');
    map.put('myCheckBox', JSON.stringify(userData));

    Setting node ids
    The ids of each node can be set in the FXML by:

    1. Setting the fx:id property (which ensures uniqueness when using an IDE). When the FXML is processed, the fx:id will be copied to the id as long as no explicit id is set for the node.
    2. Setting the id property directly, in which case the fx:id may or may not also be used.

    Attaching callbacks
    For each node in the LinkedHashMap<String, Object>, a Java listener is attached during initialisation. This listener passes events to the JavaScript callbacks as follows:

    1. If a function is defined in the callback parent object that has a name equivalent to the nodes's id appended with "_callback", that function will be called.
    2. If not, if a function is defined in the callback parent object that has a name equivalent to node's shortened, lower case class name appended with "$callback", that function will be called.

    The callback parent object might then look as follows:
    fxml$callbacks = {
    myButton_callback: function (...) {
    ...
    },
    checkbox$callback: function (...){
    ...
    }
    }

    The default controller always runs JavaScript callbacks the JavaFX Platform thread.

    Note that:
    1. If objects share an id, they will also share a callback.
    2. If callbacks are based on the class name, they will be shared by all objects of that class lacking an id.

    Callback arguments
    The following are passed as arguments to the callback functions:

    1. A reference to the node that generated the callback
    2. A reference to the event that generated the callback
    3. The value associated with this node's key in the LinkedHashMap<String, Object>
    4. The data string that was supplied as a parameter to the start method or by a subsequent call the FXWebApp setData method.
    When callbacks are shared, because two or more nodes share an id or node class names are being used to identify the callback, the third and fourth input parameters will be common to each of those objects.

    Multiple calls to initController
    Although it is anticipated that the initController method will generally be called only once, it may be called repeatedly to update/change callbacks. Each call to initController:

    1. Installs a Java listener/JavaScript callback pair if none presently exists
    2. Replaces the existing listener/callback pair if they do exist

    CREATING WINDOWS EXTERNAL TO THE HTML DOCUMENT
    An FXWebApp instance is always embedded in the hosting HTML frame. The FXWebApp createWindow method allows an embedded FXWebApp instance to create new JavaFX windows external to the hosting frame e.g. to display supplementary information when a button in the main document is clicked.

    To create such a window call the the createWindow method on an existing application embedded as above:
    var myWindow = getElementById(appName).createWindow(fxml, data, callbacks);
    This returns an FXWebWindow instance in "myWindow". This class subclasses FXWebApp and supports all methods associated with it. The arguments to the createWindow method define the FXML, data and callback object to be associated with the FXWebWindow similarly to when creating an FXWebApp instance.

    • fxml is a string containing the FXML. It may be short-form or fully-formed FXML as described above for fxml-content elements within an HTML document. If FXML is supplied from file, this should be loaded as a string first using JavaScript.
    • data a string containing data that will be passed to any callbacks
    • callbacks a string naming the JavaScript variable in the host context that defines the callbacks.

    FXWebWindow instances are "owned" by the FXWebApp instance that created them. A list of owned FXWebWindows for an embedded application can be retrieved with:
    getElementById(appName).getOwnedWindows()
    which returns an ArrayList.

    HELPER METHODS EXPOSED TO JAVASCRIPT FROM FXWebApp
    FXWebApp uses the highest node in the hierarchy of the user-supplied FXML code as the reference point, or root, for its code. The root is always a JavaFX Pane or subclass of Pane.
    The root node is added to a JavaFX Scene which is then added to a Stage when the application is first embedded.
    The getScene and getStage methods search from the root node. If the root is moved to a new, user-created, Scene or Stage these methods will return the current Scene or Stage.
    Nodes in the hierarchy can be located by using the JavaFX lookup and lookupAll methods which behave rather like JavaScript getElementById and getElementByClassName methods. For example:

    var button = document.getElementById(appName).lookup(#myButton)

    will return a reference to the JavaFX node with an id of "myButton" while

    var node = document.getElementById(appName).lookupAll(".className")

    will return a Set<Node> listing all nodes with the specified CSS class name.

    lookup is shorthand for getRoot().lookup while {lookupAll is short for getRoot().lookupAll. To search from the Scene, use getScene().lookup.
    Java methods my be invoked from JavaScript on these references e.g.:

    var button = document.getElementById(appName).lookup(#myButton);
    myButton.setText("My new label");

    However, users should take care to ensure that code is run on the JavaFX Platform thread when accessing JavaFX nodes. The FXWebApp class provides methods to make this easier:

    var app = document.getElementById(appName);
    app.runFX(function(){
    var myButton = app.lookup('#myButton');
    myButton.setText("My new label");
    }) ;

    An alternative form of this call allows arguments to be supplied:

    var app = document.getElementById(appName);
    app.runFX(function(args){
    var myButton = app.lookup(args[0);
    myButton.setText(args[1);
    }, ["#myButton", "My new label"]);

    Note the use of square brackets on the last line. These are required even when there is only one argument.

    The runFX methods post a request for the JavaScript function to be called from the Platform thread queue. The methods do not block while the function is run and can not return a result.
    If you need to return a result, equivalent blocking methods are supplied:

    • runAndWaitFX blocks and returns the result when the callback completes
    • runAndGoFX does not block and returns a FutureTask instance. Progress can be monitored in JavaScript by calling the isDone method on this object. Calling its get method will block until isDone is true and will return the result from the callback method.
      The FutureTask instance is also passed as an input to the callback, which may therefore call the isCancelled function and terminate callback execution as required.

    Trivial examples are shown below:
    runFXAndWait:

    var app = document.getElementById(appName);
    var newLabel = app.runAndWaitFX(function(){
    var myButton = app.lookup('#myButton');
    myButton.setText("My new label");
    return myButton.getText();
    }) ;

    var app = document.getElementById(appName);
    var newLabel = app.runAndWaitFX(function(args){
    var myButton = app.lookup(args[0]);
    myButton.setText(args[1]);
    return myButton.getText();
    }, ["#myButton", "My new label"]);

    runFXAndGo:

    var app = document.getElementById(appName);
    var task = app.runAndGoFX(function(future){
    var myButton = app.lookup('#myButton');
    if (future.isCancelled()) return null;
    myButton.setText("My new label");
    return myButton.getText();
    }) ;
    ...// User-supplied JavaScript continues running here
    var result=task.get()// This blocks until the task completes (or is canceled) and returns the result

    var app = document.getElementById(appName);
    var task = app.runAndGoFX(function(args, future){
    var myButton = app.lookup(args[0]);
    if (future.isCancelled()) return null;
    myButton.setText(args[1]);
    return myButton.getText();
    }, ["#myButton", "My new label"]);
    ...// User-supplied JavaScript continues running here
    var result=task.get()// This blocks until the task completes (or is canceled) and returns the result

    Use runFX, runAndWaitFX and runAndGoFX methods only when needed as they use the JavaFX Platform thread. Potentially lengthy operations such as file I/O or HTTP requests should be avoided in these functions. This is particularly so with runAndWaitFX which blocks until the supplied function completes.
    • Adding more helper functions
      The HostUtilitiesInterface defines an interface that implements by custom Java classes to provide additional helper functions.
      A host utilities instance can be retrieved by call the getUtils method of the application. It can be set by calling setUtils("className").
      Custom host utility classes can therefore be added to the Java code if it is recompiled. The following assumptions are made, EITHER:
      1. The utilities class has a no-argument constructor and implements only static methods
      2. The utilities class has a constructor which takes the FXWebApp instance as input and can therefore provide provides that need a reference to the application as well as static methods.

    Notes:

    1. Both Oracle and OpenJDK versions of dtjava.js have some issues: {1} Synchronous script loading is assumed. [2} Chrome is not supported on Mac. A revised version of the open-source dtjava.js that addresses these issues is bundled with this code. Also note that Java support, which uses NPAPI, will be discontinued in Chrome as of Chrome release 43.

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public void start(javafx.stage.Stage primaryStage)
        Specified by:
        start in class javafx.application.Application

      • initController

        public boolean initController()
        Method to initialise a FXWebAppController instance associated with this FXWebApp instance. The controller is instantiated, but not initialised, in the start() method. This method requires the callbacks JS member to have been defined when the start() method was called. Conditions required to install callbacks are that the callbacks property of this instance are neither null nor empty, and also that the host context is defined. If the host context is not defined, the callbacks property will be set to null, allowing it to be set subsequently through a call to initController(callbacks) variant of this method.
        Returns:
        true if the conditions required to install the callbacks are satisfied - false otherwise.

      • initController

        public boolean initController(java.lang.String callbacks)
        Method to initialise a FXWebAppController instance associated with this FXWebApp instance. The controller is instantiated, but not initialised, in the start() method. This method allows the callbacks JS member to be defined on-the-fly instead of in the start() method. Conditions required to install callbacks are that the callbacks argument is neither null nor empty, and also that the host context is defined. If the host context is not defined, the callbacks property of this instance will be set to null, allowing it to be set subsequently through a further call to initController(callbacks).
        Parameters:
        callbacks - name of the host context variable containing the callbacks.
        Returns:
        true if the conditions required to install the callbacks are satisfied - false otherwise.

      • getCallbacks

        public java.lang.String getCallbacks()
        Returns the name of the host context object containing the callbacks.
        Returns:
        the host context object name.

      • getRoot

        public javafx.scene.layout.Pane getRoot()
        Returns the root node associated with this FXWebApp instance. The root is the top level container defined in the FXML file provided to the start() method.
        Returns:
        the root node

      • getScene

        public javafx.scene.Scene getScene()
        Returns the scene presently associated with the root of this FXWebApp instance. The Scene is found by calling getScene on the root object.
        Returns:
        the Scene

      • getStage

        public javafx.stage.Stage getStage()
        Returns the window presently associated with the root of this FXWebApp instance. The Window is found by calling getStage on the Scene returned by the gatScene method.
        Returns:
        the window

      • getFxml

        public java.lang.String getFxml()
        Returns the fxml used to create this root. Used primarily for debugging. The return fxml is that provided to the FXML loader, including any changes that may have been made in the start() method (such as adding headers).
        Returns:
        the fxml String

      • getObjectMap

        public java.util.LinkedHashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> getObjectMap()
        Deprecated. 

      • getCallbackObjectMap

        public java.util.LinkedHashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> getCallbackObjectMap()
        Returns a LinkedHashMap<String, Object> specifying those objects that have callbacks associated with them. The keys for the map are the String ids returned by the getId() method called on the underlying JavaFX objects. Note that this requires the ids to be unique. The values associated with each key are user-specified objects that may be passed as arguments to the JavaScript callback associated with the JavaFX object via the FXWebAppControllerInterface implementation. Note, that this is implementation specific: the FXWebAppControllerInterface does not require the callbackObjectMap to be supported.
        Returns:
        the map.

      • getUtil

        public HostUtilitiesInterface getUtil()
        Returns:
        the hostUtilities instance

      • setUtil

        public java.lang.String setUtil(java.lang.String name)

      • getData

        public java.lang.String getData()
        Returns a user-specified data String. Typically, this String will be JSON and allows data to be specified in this FXWebApp instance that can be passed to the callbacks invoked through the FXWebAppControllerInterface. Note, that this is implementation specific: the FXWebAppControllerInterface does not require the callbackObjectMap to be supported.
        Returns:
        the data as a String

      • setData

        public void setData(java.lang.String data)
        Sets a user-specified data String. Typically, this String will be JSON and allows data to be specified in this FXWebApp instance that can be passed to the callbacks invoked through the FXWebAppControllerInterface. Note, that this is implementation specific: the FXWebAppControllerInterface does not require the callbackObjectMap to be supported.
        Parameters:
        data - the data String

      • runAndWaitFX

        public static java.lang.Object runAndWaitFX(netscape.javascript.JSObject callback)
                                     throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                            java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException
        Used here to simulate a Platform.runAndWait which JavaFX Platform does not provide. The supplied callback will run on the Platform thread, and the method will block until the callback has completed.
        Parameters:
        callback - the code to run
        Returns:
        the output from the code
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - if the code is interrupted
        java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException - if a an exception occurs during execution

      • runAndWaitFX

        public static java.lang.Object runAndWaitFX(netscape.javascript.JSObject callback,
                                            netscape.javascript.JSObject data)
                                     throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                            java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException
        Used here to simulate a Platform.runAndWait which JavaFX Platform does not provide. The supplied callback will run on the Platform thread, and the method will block until the callback has completed.
        Parameters:
        callback - the code to run
        data - a data object to be passed to the callback as input
        Returns:
        the output from the code
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - if the code is interrupted
        java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException - if a an exception occurs during execution

      • runAndGoFX

        public static java.util.concurrent.FutureTask<java.lang.Object> runAndGoFX(netscape.javascript.JSObject callback)
                                                                    throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                                                           java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException
        Queues a callback for execution on the Platform thread and returns control to the caller. This method returns a FutureTask<Object> to the caller. Users can poll the status of the running task by calling its isDone method. For details see here. Calling get method on the FutureTask will block execution until isDone returns true and will return the object returned by the callback.
        Parameters:
        callback - the code to run
        Returns:
        a FutureTask<Object>
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - if the code is interrupted
        java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException - if a an exception occurs during execution

      • runAndGoFX

                                                                           netscape.javascript.JSObject data)
                                                                    throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
                                                                           java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException
        Queues a callback for execution on the Platform thread and returns control to the caller. This method returns a FutureTask<Object> to the caller. Users can poll the status of the running task by calling its isDone method. For details see here. Calling get method on the FutureTask will block execution until isDone returns true and will return the object returned by the callback.

        Returns:

      • getOwnedWindows

        public java.util.ArrayList<FXWebApp.FXWebWindow> getOwnedWindows()
        Returns an ArrayList of FXWebWindow instances owned by this FXWebApp instance.
        Returns:
        the list of ownedWindows

      • createWindow

        public FXWebApp.FXWebWindow createWindow(java.lang.String fxml,
                                         java.lang.String data,
                                         java.lang.String callbacks)
        Creates a new JavaFX window external to the host browser page. Returns an FXWebWindow instance "owned" by the creating FXWebApp instance. FXWebWindow subclasses the FXWebApp but instances of FXWebWindow are not embedded in the host document.
        Parameters:
        fxml - the FXML describing the required JavaFX scene.
        data - a string containing data (typically as Json) that will be passed to the callbacks.
        callbacks - the name of the JavaScript object in the host context containing the callbacks (if any).
        Returns:
        a reference to the created FXWebWindow instance.
